Meybur es de tez trigueña, cabello negro y baja estatura (sentada al centro usa blusa rosa), su lengua materna es el guaraní y habla español. Su vida la comparte con su pareja que trabaja y con sus hijos que estudian en la escuela, viven en una casa propia construida de madera que sólo cuenta con energía eléctrica y agua de pozo. La necesidad por mejorar su negocio lo llevó a  liderar la banca de emprendimiento con negocios como; venta de comida, venta de ropa de segunda mano, artesanía en cuero, elaboración de sombreros de sao, llantería, cerrajería, venta de gaseosas y venta de huevos. Su negocio es el servicio de peluquería, en un lugar habilitado como cuarto en su domicilio, ella se ocupa del corte y peinado del cabello, sus clientes son mujeres y niños del lugar, realiza cortes, peinados, tientes y otros, “abrí mi negocio por impulso unas amigas que fueron mis primeros clientes…” comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es que cuenta con clientes, la desventaja es la falta de dinero para comprar herramientas de trabajo como]; tijeras, secadoras, toallas, tientes y otros. Su sueño es estabilizar su negocio, ella desea comprar herramientas de peluquería para su salón de belleza. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 1 año que realiza esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Meybur solicita un préstamo para comprar herramientas de peluquería para equipar su salón de belleza.
texts.en:
Meybur is a 25-year-old woman. She lives with her partner, has two children of 4 and 5 years, and has a hairdresser's shop.

She is a good mother - independent and very hard-working. She is doing her business in the neighborhood of "El torno" [engl. "the lathe"], a rural area characterized by having agricultural production spread throughout the city.

Meybur is dark-skinned, black-haired, with a small stature (she is sitting in the center with a pink blouse). Her first language is Guaraní and she speaks Spanish. She is spending her life with her husband, who is working, and her children, who are in school. They live in their own house, which is built out of wood and only has electricity and well water.

The need to improve her business lead her to the Business Bank, which has businesses like food sales, second hand clothing sales, leather crafts, straw hat making, tire shops, soda sales, and egg sales.

Her business is the service of a hairdresser in a place about a block from her home. She cuts and combs hair. Her customers are women and children from the area. She is cutting, combing, dying etc. "I opened my business on the suggestion of some friends, who were my first clients", she says.

The good thing about her business is that she has customers. The bad thing is that she is missing money to buy tools to work with, like scissors, blow dryers, towels, hair dye and so on.

Her dream is to establish her business. She wishes to buy hairdresser's tools for equipping her beauty salon.

This is the first loan with the institution in the one year she has had this business.

For these reasons, Meybur is requesting a loan to buy hairdresser's tools for equipping her beauty salon.

loans.use: to buy hairdresser's tool for equipping her beauty salon.

loans.name: Glitzelle

texts.en:
Glitzelle works in a fish selling business to earn a living and to help her husband in raising their children. They have two children, ages seven and six years old. Her husband works hard as a driver and a laborer. With much effort, their earnings are enough only for their daily expenses, school fees, and bills.

That is why Glitzelle decided to borrow money for additional capital to continue operating her business. She needs the money to buy more fish to sell to increase her income. Glitzelle is a 25-year-old woman whose only goal in life is to have enough money to send her children to school so they can be professionals and have better lives in the future.

loans.use: to buy more fish

loans.name: Marilen

texts.en:
Marilen is a married woman with four children. She is 35 years old and all four of her children are in school. Marilen is a very hard-working entrepreneur. She has a general store business in the Philippines and has been in this business for five years.

Marilen requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more items like canned goods, snack foods, and personal care products. In the future, she would like to save enough money that she can continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase more items like canned goods, snack foods, and personal care products.

loans.name: Las Propias Originales Group

texts.es:
Mirtha continúa con su negocio de venta de ropa de segunda mano. El crédito que obtuvo lo invirtió comprando  ropa infantil variada, el pago de sus cuotas fue puntual porque pudo vender su mercadería (LA PRIMERA DE LA DERECHA , POLERA BLANCA Y CARTERA NEGRA ). Actualmente su negocio se estabiliza y espera tener mejores ventas en épocas de fin de año, “la ropa de los niños se rompe todos los días…”comenta. la ventaja de su negocio es que la mercadería rota constantemente, la desventaja es la falta de dinero para renovar la mercadería. Su sueño es abrir una tienda de ropa, Ella desea comprar ropa infantil por mayor para aprovechar las fiestas de fin de año y mejorar sus ventas. Esta es la 2 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 2 años que viene desarrollando esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Mirtha solicita un préstamo para comprar ropa infantil por mayor para aprovechar las fiestas de fin de año.
texts.en:
Mirtha still has her business of selling second hand clothing. She invested the loan she was granted into buying various toddler's clothes. She repaid punctually, because she was able to sell her goods.

(She is the one on the right, with the white shirt and black handbag.)

At the moment her business is stabilizing and her goal is to increase her sales at the end of the year. "Children's clothes break every day", she says.

The good thing about her business is, that her goods sell quickly. The bad thing is, that she is missing money to renew her stock. Her goal is to open a clothing store. She wants to buy toddler's clothing at wholesale to make use of the holidays at the end of the year and increase her sales.

This is her second loan with the institution in the two years she has been developing this business.

For these reasons, Mirtha is requesting a loan to buy toddler's clothing at wholesale to make use of the holidays at the end of the year.

loans.use: to buy toddler's clothing at wholesale to make use of the holidays at the end of the year.

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia is a married woman with one child. She describes herself as loyal. Sophia operates a retail business where she sells clothes and she has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. She says her biggest business challenge is inadequate working capital.

Sophia will use this KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes. She hopes that in the future, she will be a wholesaler. She will use the anticipated profits to add more stock to her business.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
As a married mother of four children, Mary Jane works hard to support her family. She has a business buying and selling bamboo in the Philippines and has been sustaining her business activities through her past seven loans from NWTF.

Mary Jane is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF in order to buy more bamboo to resell. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more bamboo to resell.

loans.name: Iluminada

texts.en:
Iluminada works hard to support her family. She is married and has a business buying and selling bananas in the Philippines. Iluminada has been in this business for 27 years now.

Iluminada requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional bananas to sell. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional bananas to sell.

loans.name: Jenalyn

texts.en:
As a married mother of two children, Jenelyn works hard to support her family. She has a farming business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from a general store.

Jenelyn is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF in order to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies for her farming business. She has been sustaining her business activities through her past five loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. Jenelyn hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: María Eduviges

texts.es:
María, de 42 años de edad, está acompañada, vive con su pareja, sus 2 hijos y su madre, ella es una mujer muy trabajadora y emprendedora, estudio hasta bachillerato, sus hijos se encuentran estudiando y su esposo emigró hacia los Estados Unidos de América.

María, tiene un negocio de bisutería y arreglos florales, este negocio lo tiene desde hace más de 20 años, decidió aprender la elaboración de flores y otros artículos en unos cursos que estaban impartiendo cerca de su comunidad, desde entonces decidió emprender su propio negocio y día con día va en ascenso; para llegar al negocio tiene que viajar todos los días 20 minutos. 

María, necesita el préstamo para comprar materiales para elaboración de flores, porque se acerca la temporada en donde se vende bastante los arreglos florales, que es el día de los santos difuntos.

Ella sueña con colocar otro negocio y además quiere en un futuro sus hijos se conviertan en profesionales, ya que ella quiere formar su patrimonio para que en un futuro a sus hijos nos les falte lo necesario.
texts.en:
María, age 42, is in a relationship. She lives with her life partner, their two children, and her mother. She is a very hard-working and enterprising woman. She went to school through high school. Her children go to school, and her husband emigrated to the United States.

María has a jewelry and floral arrangement business. She has had this business for over 20 years. She decided to learn to arrange flowers and other items in courses that were being given close to her community. After that she decided to undertake her own business. It is on the rise day by day. In order to get to her business she has to travel 20 minutes every day.

María needs the loan to buy materials to make floral arrangements. The time when plenty of floral arrangements are sold, All Saints Day, is near.

She dreams of arranging another business. She also wants her children to become professionals in the future. She wants to create a legacy so that her children will not lack the necessities in the future.

loans.use: to buy materials to make floral arrangements.

loans.name: Eugenio Santo

texts.es:
Eugenio, de 59 años de edad, es agricultor de profesión, estudio hasta segundo grado, es soltero, su esposa falleció hace muchos años.

Eugenio, se dedica al trabajo y mantenimiento de café, esta labor la ha practicado desde hace más de 30 años, debido a que es la base fundamental de sus ingresos, esta labor la hace por herencia de sus padres, pero también trabaja prestando servicio como transportista con un camión de donde obtienen ingresos.

El préstamo lo necesita para comprar insumos como fertilizantes agrícolas y para pagar el mantenimiento de la finca cafetalera.

Sus sueños son tener sus cultivos en buenas condiciones como hace 6 años atrás y mejorar su vivienda.
texts.en:
Eugenio, age 59, is a farmer by profession. He went to school through the second grade. He is single; his wife died many years ago. Eugenio's work is with coffee and its maintenance. He has done this work for over 30 years. It is the fundamental source of his income. He inherited this work from his parents. He also provides transportation services with a truck, and he gets income from that.

He needs the loan to buy supplies like fertilizers and to pay for the maintenance of the coffee farm.

His dreams are to have his crops be in good condition like six years ago and to improve his house.

loans.use: to buy supplies like fertilizers and to pay for the mainentance of his coffee farm.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase a solar system to replace the use of candles with electricity and give her children a better quality of life and opportunities.

loans.name: Bishika's Group

texts.en:
Bishika is a friendly and a differently abled woman of the age of 28. She is standing to the right-hand side in the photograph. She is married and has two children.

She has been working since an early age in order to support her low-income household. She has a very friendly family, including her in-laws. They live in a rural area in Narshinghpur of Odisha, India.

In order for her family to have an income, all family members are trying to earn money in some way. Each one works in any way they can. Bishika's main and most stable business is livestock breeding. She breeds and sells livestock. Her husband helps her with the business. She looks after the livestock and also sells the milk.

The livestock breeding business brings Bishika a good and stable income. Therefore, she would like to expand this business. She, along with her fellow group member, is requesting a loan amount of 30,000 INR.

She needs to purchase some heads of livestock for breeding and then selling. She will use her portion of the loan amount for purchasing livestock. She hopes that her business expansion will be successful, and bring in a higher income in order to cover her family's needs.

loans.use: to purchase more livestock.

loans.name: Nueva Concepcion Group

texts.en:
In the southwest region of the country of Guatemala, Cabricán is a municipality that rests about 40 kilometers from Quetzaltenango, a major city in the region, also known as Xela.

In this chilly rural town live 10 women of the trust bank “Nueva Concepción.” Their group name was inspired by the Catholic Virgin Mary. Between 20 and 60 years of age, most of these women are married and have children who receive formal education.

Olga is a 36-year-old member of the trust bank with a large family of six children, whom she cares for with her husband. She could only study to second grade, but all of her children are studying or have finished secondary school.

For her business, Olga has a food cart where she sells chicken tacos and vegetables with her husband. With the loan that she is requesting, she will buy products to restock her food cart, such as chicken, vegetables, spices, and corn for the tortillas.

These ladies have business like buying and selling vegetables and selling artisan products, such as “cortes,” traditional skirts, “huipiles,” blouses, and other typical textiles, which they weave and embroider themselves.

In the time they have had as clients of Friendship Bridge, the women of “Nueva Concepción” have gained knowledge in many areas, and developed techniques for improving their businesses and lifestyles, thanks to the monthly chats. The Kiva loans make it possible for these women to forge a brighter future for themselves and their families.

loans.use: to buy products to restock her food cart, such as chicken, vegetables, spices, and corn for the tortillas.

loans.name: Anupama's Group

texts.en:
Anupama is a charming and a humble lady standing to the right-hand side in the photograph. She is a resident of a small village in Narsinghpur, Odisha, India. She is a divorcee and has one son in her care. She lives with her mother and her son in her parental house.

In order to support herself, she is engaged in a candle-making business. She chose this business because the area where she lives has erratic power supply conditions, and these candles could solve the purpose in this kind of situation.

She, along with her fellow group member, is requesting a loan amount of 30,000 INR. She will use her portion of the loan amount to purchase wax and threads, and repair her candle-making machine so that she can increase her efficiency and make a voluminous number of candles in less period of time. This will enable her to satisfy the demand of a large customer base and increase her earnings.

Anupama is eagerly awaiting for your kind hearts to help her.

loans.use: to purchase wax and threads, and repair her candle-making machine.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
La socia Victoria  se dedica al negocio de crianza de pollos y cuyes, la socia los pollos los hace engordar y crecer y luego los vende en las diferentes mercados, la socia ya tiene varios años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es tener un local donde pueda vender los pollos y cuyes. La socia solicita le crédito para comprar pollos y cuyes y alimentos para los pollos y cuyes.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
The member, Victoria, raises chickens and guinea pigs for a living. She raises and fattens the chickens and then sells them at the various farmers' markets. She has had this business for several years and is doing very well.

The member's dream is to have a shop where she can sell the chickens and guinea pigs. The member is requesting the loan to buy chickens and guinea pigs and feed for the chickens and guinea pigs.

The member is happy to have the loan and promises to comply with the installment payments.

loans.use: to buy chickens and guinea pigs and feed for the chickens and guinea pigs.

loans.name: Rosas De Pascua Group

texts.en:
The small neighborhood of El Rancho in the town of Santa Maria Chiquimula is where the Friendship Bridge Trust Bank group “Rosas de Pascua” is located. The area is largely agricultural, producing corn, beans and wheat. Some in the area make beautiful traditional textiles and jackets. The population speaks the Maya dialect of Kiche and some Spanish.

The president of the Trust Bank is 37-year-old Maria, who was able to attend school until the fourth grade. She is married with four children who have all been through primary school. Her husband is both a mechanic and a bricklayer.

Maria has a traditional textile business and has recently joined this Trust Bank to infuse capital into her business. This will be her very first loan. She buys and sells the colorful traditional blouses called “huipiles,” as well as the intricately woven skirts, or “cortes."

Maria wants to have plenty of colors and styles available for her customers who not only see her merchandise in the local market but also in nearby ones. Her dream is to generate enough income to open a convenience store where she will sell items that are useful on an everyday basis.

The educational component of the monthly meetings is of vital importance for the women. They learn to effectively manage their loans with information about planning, budgeting, pricing, marketing, accounting and customer service.

Kiva lenders are greatly appreciated by Maria and her friends in the “Rosas de Pascua” Trust Bank for their generosity in funding loans. Thank you!

loans.use: to buy plenty of colors and styles of textiles for sale.

loans.name: Eulalia

texts.en:
Eulalia hails from the town of Pilar, Bohol. She owns a sari-sari (variety) store. She caters mostly to neighbors and local settlers in the community. She sells goods ranging from eggs, seasonings, assorted canned goods and biscuits to soft drinks.

She is married woman and has six grown children.

She faces challenges in operating her business, particularly where the liquidity of capital is concerned. Eulalia is asking for a loan to buy assorted groceries like canned goods, seasonings and soft drinks.

She would like to maintain the contents of her store and be able to cope with the daily demand. With the help of these items, she could be able to improve her income and would like to invest in other possible business opportunities. Slowly, she could set aside some of the profits for emergency use.

In the future, she is determined that she could be successful in handling her business.

Eulalia is very grateful for your support.

loans.use: to buy assorted groceries like canned goods, seasonings and soft drinks.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a married woman with 4 children. She describes herself as honest.

Mariam operates a retail business where she sells popcorn. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of popcorn.

Her business goal is to have a big business within 5 years. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. She will use the anticipated profits to puchase additional stock.

loans.use: to buy more stock of popcorn.

loans.name: Cherry Neth

texts.en:
Cherry Neth is 34 years old and has three children. Cherry Neth is a woman, and two of her children are in school.

Cherry Neth is in the agricultural business of raising pigs in the Philippines. Cherry Neth requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to buy feeds, vitamins, and other supplies to raise her livestock.

Cherry Neth has been in this business for one year now, and has borrowed one time in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Cherry Neth would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds, vitamins and other supplies to raise her livestock.

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia is a 60-year-old widow with seven children, one of whom is still in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Alicia has a buy-and-sell bamboo business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 8,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more bamboo to sell. She has been in this business for 1 year.

She would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more bamboo to sell

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn is a 34-year-old widow with two children who are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Arlyn has a business selling root crops in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 5,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy a variety of root crops to sell. She has been in this business for 2 years.

In the future, Arlyn would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy a variety of root crops to sell.

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
Mary Grace is 34 years old and married with six children, five of whom are currently in school.

Mary Grace is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs. She has been in pig fattening for 8 years now, and has borrowed 5 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Mary Grace would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs

loans.name: Jenelyn

texts.en:
Jenelyn is 50 years old and married with one child.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Jenelyn is borrowing PHP 22,000 through NWTF in order to buy medicines and vaccines for her pigs.

Jenelyn has been raising pigs for 30 years and earns additional income from selling in a general store and ready-to-wear clothing businesses.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy medicines and vaccines for her pigs.

loans.name: Habil

texts.en:
Habil is 29 years old. He is married. Habil is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person) who lives with his family in the Bilesuvar region. He is a farmer.

Habil is a steady and successful person. He started to work in his field three years ago. Habil usually buys seeds (for fruits and vegetables) from other markets. People prefer to buy fruits and vegetables from private gardens because they are naturally raised and are healthier. People know that such products are always fresh and healthy: They are not grown with some different pesticides and aren't harmful.

During long years of work he has gained experience. Habil was taught how to cover customers' demand. Selling fruits and vegetables from houses is popular and cheaper for people than buying them in bazaars and big markets.

His biggest dream is to expand his land and to plant more seeds. But before this, Habil has to have some money and hopes Kiva lenders will support him.

loans.use: to expand his land and to plant more seeds.

loans.name: Emily Ruth

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal SANTA ROSA DE URUBAMBA.
La socia Emily Ruth tiene 57 años de edad es casada y tiene 01 hijo, la socia  alterna sus actividades diarias dedicándose a trabajar como docente en uno de los colegios de la zona, la socia lleva buen tiempo con su trabajo el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su trabajo, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de víveres para su hogar como arroz, azúcar, leche entre otros.
La socia se siente agradecida por el crédito otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
texts.en:
The member belongs to the SANTA ROSA DE URUBAMBA village bank.

The member, Emily Ruth, is 57 years old, married, with one son. The member divides her time on her daily chores, working as a teacher at one of the schools in the region. The member has had this job for some time now, and is doing well at it thanks to the effort she puts into her work every day. The member hopes to be able to keep working so she can continue supporting her family.

The member is requesting the loan to buy supplies for her household, such as rice, sugar, milk and other items.

The member is grateful for the loan she was granted and promises to comply with the scheduled installment payments.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her household, such as rice, sugar, milk and other items.

loans.name: Carol

texts.en:
Carol is 25 years old, married with one child.

Carol works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional groceries to sell in her stall such as milk, coffee, drinks, bread, canned goods, noodles, and shampoo and other personal care products.

Carol has borrowed and repaid six loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns an income from pig fattening.

Carol aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional groceries to sell in her stall such as milk, coffee, drinks, bread, canned goods, noodles, and shampoo and other personal care products.

loans.name: Racquel

texts.en:
Racquel is 36 years old, and has four children.

Racquel works hard to provide for her family. She has been running a general store in the Philippines for two years and also earns an income from buying and selling coconut wine. She requested a 5,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like canned goods, junk foods, home care products, and other groceries.

Racquel has not borrowed from NWTF before this loan. She aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, junk foods, home care products, and other groceries.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is 42 years old and married with one child in school. Caroline works very hard to provide for her family.

Caroline runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 8,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like beverages, canned goods, home care products, and other groceries.

Caroline has been in this business for 10 years and sells a variety of items such as shampoo, soap, soy sauce, biscuits, beverages, candies, diapers and other groceries.

In the future, Caroline would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like beverages, canned goods, home care products, and other groceries.

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business selling ready-to-wear in the Philippines.

She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF in order to buy more ready-to-wear items like footwear, school uniforms and other dry goods for her business. She has been in this business for four years and also earns more income from a general store and from fattening pigs.

Ester has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from NWTF.

She dreams of saving enough money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy more ready-to-wear items like footwear, school uniforms and other dry goods.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a 63-year-old married woman with one child. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Gloria has a fish vending business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 12,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more fish to sell to her customers. She has been in this business for 28 years.

She would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell to her customers

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a food vending business in the Philippines.

She is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients like meat, chicken, spices, hotdogs, etc. for her food vending business. She has been in this business for 6 years and also earns more income from raising pigs.

Alma has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from NWTF.

She dreams of repairing and renovating her family home in the future.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like meat, chicken, spices, hotdogs, etc. for her food production business

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is a married woman with six children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Jocelyn is 49 years old and has three children who are presently in school.

Jocelyn has a fishing business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 9,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy fish net, gasoline for her boat, and bamboo and other materials for her fishing business.

Jocelyn has been in this business for 20 years. She would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fish net, gasoline for her boat, and bamboo and other materials for her fishing business.

loans.name: Juaraboy

texts.en: Juraboy is married and has 2 children. He lives with his family in a rural area. Juraboy works hard every day in his land for earning. Also, Juraboy has been busy with animal husbandry. He buys cows feeds some months and sells in a local market. He has repeated customers. Many local butchers are his customers. Juraboy has a great experience in this field. He is going to increase working capital and maximize profit. He is asking for a loan of 1000tjs somoni to buy cows for increasing working capital. He awaits your mercy.

loans.use: to buy cows for increasing working capital.

loans.name: Hector

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal PITUSIRAY,el banco está ubicado en el distrito de Calca ,provincia de Calca y departamento de Cusco.
El socio Hector continua dedicándose a ejercer su carrera de docente en uno de los colegios de la zona, el socio se siente agradecido por el crédito otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas, él socio es una persona responsable y empeñoso, siendo de esta manera que el socio saca adelante a su familia.

El socio solicita el crédito para la compra de materiales didácticos entre otros.
texts.en:
The member Hector belongs to the communal bank PITUSIRAY which is located in the district of Calca in Calca province and the department of Cusco.

Hector continues to earn a living working as a teacher at one of the schools in the area. He is grateful for the loan and agrees to comply with the repayment terms. Hector is a responsible and determined person which means he is able to provide for his family.

Hector is applying for a loan to buy teaching materials and other resources.

loans.use: to buy teaching materials and other resources.

loans.name: Nada

texts.en: Nada is a Lebanese married woman. She’s 46 years old and has two children. She is really attached to her family. Her husband is a retired soldier and owns a shoe shop and works tirelessly to be able to cover the heavy expenses in order to live a respectable life. Today, the fact that the new school year is coming, she is asking for a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l to pay her children educational fees. The family only target and dreams is to see those achieving higher positions.

loans.use: to pay her children educational fees

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita is a 22 year-old single woman. She lives with her parents and siblings. Her father is the main income provider for the family. She works as a photographer in a local studio.

Today, she is asking to borrow a loan from Kiva partner, Vitas s.a.l, to pay for her training course in photography. She said that after taking the loan, she will be able to attract more customers and therefore, increase her income and develop her way of living.

loans.use: to pay her training courses in photographing

loans.name: Amistad De Huayllabamba Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “LA AMISTAD DE HUAYLLABAMBA”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de Huayllabamba, perteneciente a la provincia de Urubamba y departamento de Cusco. 

La socia es la Sra. Rosa ella es viuda y tiene 60 años y tiene 7 hijos; La socia trabaja en su negocio de venta de  verduras, la socia vende platanos, naranjas y manzanas y también vende cebollas, tomates y zapallos, la socia ya tiene varios años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es tener un local donde pueda vender las verduras. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar  cebollas, zanahorias y tomates. 

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.

Los otros socios se dedican al negocio de trasporte, negocio de venta de frutas, negocio de tienda de abarrotes y negocio de venta de comida. 

La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The borrowers belong to the "La Amsted de Huayllabamba" communal bank. This bank is located in the district of Huayllabamba, in the province of Urubamba, in the department of Cusco. The borrower is Rosa. She is a 60 year old widow and has 7 children. She works selling vegetables. She sells bananas, oranges and apples. She also sells onions, tomatoes and squash. She has several years in this business, and it is going very well. Her dream is to have a locale where she can sell the vegetables.

She seeks a loan to buy onions, carrots and tomatoes. She is happy for the loan and promises to comply with the required payments. The other borrowers work in a transportation business, a business selling fruit, a grocery store business, and a business selling food. The borrower is thankful to all who form part of this dream in this manner, and promises to make the required scheduled payments.

loans.use: to buy onions, carrots and tomatoes.

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin is a married man. He has 6 children. He operates a retail business where he sells sugar, rice,soda, flour,milk, bread and other household items. He also operates M-pesa business within the shop. He has been involved in this business for 15 years. His business is located in a rural area and his primary customers are regular. He describes his biggest business challenge to be price fluctuations.

He will use the Kes 40,000 loan to add mpesa float. His business goal is to open other business branches within 5 years. This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully. He will use the anticipated profits to purchase additional stock

loans.use: to add mpesa float

loans.name: Gelaina

texts.en: Gelaina signed up for her membership with PMPC and obtained the needed capital to start her sari-sari (variety) store business. She is thankful for the capital that was extended to a small-time borrower like her. She took a loan to restock her store with basic goods like canned goods, oil, and soy sauce. In the future, she hopes to build a decent home for the family.

loans.use: to restock her store with items like canned goods, oil, and soy sauce.

loans.name: Wanjala

texts.en:
Wanjala is a married man. He has two children. He describes himself to be honest. He operates a transport business where he transports customers using his motorcycle. He has been involved in this business for two years. His business is located in a good area, and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be the rise in fuel prices.

He will use the KES 20,000 loan to maintain and repair his motorcycle. His business goal is to buy another extra motorcycle within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will be a millionaire.

This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. He will save the anticipated profits.

loans.use: to maintain and repair his motorcycle.

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
As a single parent of two children, Geraldine works hard to support her family.

She has a buy and sell coconut wine business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from general store.  Geraldine is borrowing PHP 5000 through NWTF to  buy containers of coconut wine to sell for her buy and sell coconut wine business.

Geraldine has been sustaining her business activities through her past 1 loan from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy containers of coconut wine to sell

loans.name: Narine

texts.en:
Narine from the village Lchashen of Gegharkunik region sends her greetings and thanks for her first Kiva loan that was so great and profitable for her farm. She is 30 years old and with the same pleasure and enthusiasm she is engaged in her swine breeding. With her husband, Narine breeds pigs and piglets in her farm and sell great amount of pork to butchers and also to the owners of sausage plants or supermarkets. Despite of having very good and important profession of teaching, farming takes all the time of this lady and she is busy only with it and of course her family care. They have a school-aged daughter. Narine also has nice fruit garden full of apple, pear, peach and fig trees and she skillfully sells all the harvest right from her farm to re-sellers.

This loan of 700.000 Armenian drams Narine again plans to use for the purchase of fodder for her pigs since being the owner of big farm she knows that having not enough fodder means also to have a lot of hardships in farming and low income from it as well.

loans.use: for the purchase of fodder for her pigs in order to have more income from her swine breeding.

loans.name: Lucina

texts.en:
Lucina is 50 years old and married with four children. Lucina works very hard to provide for them.

Lucina runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like spices, snack foods, home care products, and other groceries.

Lucina has been in this business for one year and sells a variety of items such as condiments, toothpaste, snack foods, and other groceries.

In the future, Lucina would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like spices, snack foods, home care products, and other groceries.

loans.name: Francisco Antonio

texts.es:
Francisco es propietario de un taller de estructuraras metálicas, vive con su esposa y un hijo que tiene la edad de un año, su negocio lo estableció hace tres años, en sus inicios no contaba con el equipo adecuado y sus clientes no eran muchos, poco a poco ha ido mejorando su negocio, él aprendió este oficio de su padre, normalmente trabaja solo, cuando la demanda es alta contrata ayudantes, tiene un horario de trabajo de ocho de la mañana a cinco de la tarde, su ventaja es que ya tiene muchos clientes establecidos.
Comprará un compresor nuevo, hierro, láminas, tubos, entre otros materiales, tendrá equipo en buenas condiciones para continuar trabajando, la inversión es necesaria ya que el equipo que actualmente tiene en su negocio le está fallando, espera administrar de la mejor manera el crédito para sacar el mayor provecho.
Sus proyectos son mantener su negocio funcionando, atender nuevos clientes y tener un estilo de vida digno.
texts.en:
Francisco is the owner of a metal workshop. He lives with his wife and a year-old child.

He learned this work from his father and started the business three years ago. At the beginning, he didn't have adequate equipment and his clients were few, but little by little he has been improving. Normally he works alone, hiring assistants when the demand is high. His work hours are 8 am to 5 pm, his advantage is that he already has many existing customers.

He will buy a new compressor, iron, sheeting, pipes, and more. He will then have the equipment in good working order, which will allow him to keep working. This investment is necessary because the equipment is now failing.

He will make optimal use of the loan to the best advantage. His plans are to keep his business going, serve new clients, and earn a decent life.

loans.use: to buy a new compressor, iron, sheeting, pipes, and more. He will have the equipment in good condition to continue working.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Meet Elizabeth, a mother of two who practices mixed farming in Kapsowar, Kenya. She has been in this business for 10 years! She makes a living farming and selling her produce, which includes milk, eggs and crops, at the local market. She also does some side hustle businesses for extra income.

Elizabeth spends most of her time pasturing her cows. Currently, though, she is facing a big challenge of transporting feed from the store to the animal shed.

Today, Elizabeth is seeking a loan to purchase cereals. Farm supplies are increasingly becoming expensive by the day. Farmers who seek cheaper sources end up buying "fake" seeds that either do not germinate or do not produce quality seeds. With your loan, Elizabeth is going to afford seeds for planting from recommended sources to ensure her crops grow healthy and productive.

Profits made from this harvest will be reinvested into the business for growth. When asked “How will this loan benefit your family?” Elizabeth replied, “I will start a cereals business which will increase my family’s cash flow.”

. Kindly make a loan to this hardworking Kenyan woman!

loans.use: to purchase cereal seeds.

loans.name: Divine Favour Group

texts.en:
Greater favour will allow you to take on bigger opportunities, new responsibilities, and achieve higher goals in life. This is the motto that has made these four ladies achieve great strides in their businesses. Mizikayifani and her three friends make up the group Divine Favour. They strongly believe that hard work and dedication are necessary for one to be successful in their very competitive lines of business.

Mizikayifani is in the poultry and tuck-shop business. She is a 47 year old mother of two primary school going children. Mizikayifani specialises in breeding road runners instead of the usual broilers. She feels that road-runners are cheaper to breed and bring in more profit. The different line of business she has ventured into has seen her poultry business grow tremendously. However, managing both businesses has been very challenging for Mizikayifani. She rarely had enough capital to finance and keep both businesses thriving. Mizikayifani’s business almost collapsed when she was charged a very high interest rate at an informal lender she had gone to seek financial support from. It was during this period that Mizikayifani and her friends found out about Thrive Microfinance.

They joined Thrive in September 2015 and received training as well as financial assistance, which included very fair interest rates. With a loan from Thrive, Mizikayifani hopes to boost her tuck-shop stock records and grow her poultry business.

loans.use: To increase her flock of road-runners.

loans.name: Kusimudzirana Group

texts.en:
The sky is the limit when it comes to dedicated businesswoman Mejury, who is specialized in tailoring and handicrafts.

Early in the morning, Mejury, a member of the Kusimudzirana Group, will collect already welded frames and weaving materials and get busy. She is specialized in making kitchen tables and chairs, television stands, garden chairs and sofas, among other numerous handcrafted products.

As a married woman with four children, Mejury learned how to use her skills and abilities to earn a living, as she believes that through the work of her hands, she will reach her goals in life. She has a certificate in Clothing Technology and Business Management which she did at Pioneer Vocational Training College in 2000.

However, she is facing challenges in the handcrafting business, as there is a poor market in her local suburb of Chitungwiza. More so, customers are easier to attract if one has a large stock of finished products, and she doesn’t have adequate capital. Again in her tailoring business, she faces the challenge of minimal capital in order for her to meet some orders of large quantities.

Due to massive power cuts in the day, she is sometimes forced to have sleepless nights on her sewing machine as she constantly receives big orders from her rural neighborhood schools.

As Kusimudzirana Group, they approached Thrive, where they received training. They benefited on knowing the essence of savings and record keeping.

Mejury is in need of a loan of $300 to buy tailoring and handcrafting material, as well as acquiring a space in areas were market levels for her products are quite higher.

A collective group loan of $950 will help Kusimudzirana Group members to achieve their goals in their businesses.

loans.use: to buy tailoring and handcrafting materials for her business of making kitchen tables and chairs, television stands, garden chairs and sofas, among other numerous other handcrafted products.

loans.name: Kushanda Group

texts.en:
The above ladies make up the Kushanda group, the group is based in Chitungwiza. The group is made up of three friends who are very hard working. ‘Kushanda’ is a Shona word which means Hard Working, these women strongly believe that nothing worth having comes easy. 
In this group there is Shirley who was a former cross border trader in the early 1990s, far left in the photo. Shirley started buying clothes in town and selling them at flea markets and in her local area. The business was not sustainable as many people could not pay her on time, and sometimes matured into bad debts. Shirley thought it wise to go to rural areas to exchange clothes, buckets, and groceries for agricultural products like nuts, maize and beans. Shirley has been able to feed the family since her husband retired five years ago. Shirley was also able to send grandchildren to school because of her hardworking mentality.
Shirley is a diligent woman who wants a loan from Thrive to buy more products like buckets plates and clothes to grow her barter trade business which has grown very popular in these days. Shirley and other members of the group were very much informed by the trainings at Thrive microfinance and they expressed much appreciation.

loans.use: to buy more products like buckets, plates and clothes to grow her barter trade business.

loans.name: Señor De Los Milagros De Chimpahuaylla Group

texts.es:
La socia Dora Delia, ella pertenece al banco comunal “Señor de los Milagros de Chimpahuaylla” de la ciudad del Cusco – Perú.
La socia Dora Delia continua  dedicándose a enseñar en uno de los colegios de la ciudad, la socia es una persona responsable y empeñosa, la socia lleva años dedicándose a trabajar el cual le trae satisfacciones personales entre otros, siendo de esta manera que la socia saca adelante a su familia, la socia se siente agradecida por el crédito y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de un electrodoméstico.
Los socios en general se sienten  agradecidos  por el crédito otorgado y se comprometen a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
texts.en:
Dora Delia is a member of the "Senor of the Miracles of Chimpahuaylla" communal bank located in the city of Cusco in Peru.

Dora Delia continues to dedicate herself to her work, teaching in one of the city's schools. She is a responsible and enterprising person who has been devoted to her work for many years. It brings her personal satisfaction, among other positive things, and is the means whereby she advances her family. Dora Delia is grateful for the loan and promises to comply with her established schedule of payments.

Dora Delia is requesting the loan to purchase an electrical appliance.

The members in general feel gratitude for the offer of a loan and they all promise to comply with their established payments on schedule.

[Translator's note: The white hat in the photo designates a person of recognized rank in the community.]

loans.use: purchase an electrical appliance.

loans.name: Nada

texts.en: Nada is a 54 year old Lebanese widow woman living with her five children, three of them still attending school. Her oldest children are the main income source in the family to satisfy the requirements of life. Despite the bad financial situation, she is requesting today a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l to pay her children’s educational fees. She said that the loan will surely help her to register them with the coming school year what makes her very happy.

loans.use: to pay her children’s educational fees

loans.name: Nympha

texts.en:
Nympha runs a shop selling personal products like shampoo, body lotion, hair gel, spray, whitening soap, deodorant, beauty creams and other kinds of perfume. Aside from that, she also takes care of mango trees to bear fruit. She purchases the materials and equipment needed like sprayers, and fertilizers. In this way, she generates other sources of income.

Nympha is 39 years old and married with two young children. Her husband is an engineer by profession.

Nympha wants to continue improving her quality of life, which is why she is requesting a loan to boost her livelihood. She would like to buy assorted stock for the store, purchase a tricycle (rickshaw) hub, and use additional capital for her mango business.

With the loan, Nympha can fill the inventory of her shop. She used the previous loan to stock her shop and wants to continue expanding it.

loans.use: to buy assorted stock for the store, purchase a tricycle (rickshaw) hub and use additional capital for her mango business.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 62 years old and married.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 6,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional boxes of groceries to sell such as milk, coffee, drinks, bread, canned goods, noodles, shampoo and other personal care products.

Erlinda has been in this business for 10 years. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional boxes of groceries to sell at her store such as milk, coffee, drinks, bread, canned goods, noodles, shampoo and other personal care products.

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fish vending business in the Philippines.

Thelma requested a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more variety of fish to sell to her customers. She has been in this business for six years now, and she would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more variety of fish to sell to her customers

loans.name: Magelyn

texts.en:
Magelyn works hard to support her family. She is married and has a general store business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for six years now.

Magelyn successfully paid back her previous loan, and now she has requested an additional loan through NWTF to further build her business. She will use the 20,000 PHP loan to buy items to sell like canned goods, sugar, milk, sugar, coffee, etc.

In the future, Magelyn would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, sugar, milk, sugar, coffee, etc.

loans.name: Vhanelyn

texts.en:
As a married parent of one child, Vhanelyn works hard to support her family.

She has a food vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buy and sell beverages.  Vhanelyn is borrowing PHP 10000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food vending business such as, sugar, fruits, etc. for her food vending business.

Vhanelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past 2 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food vending business such as, sugar, fruits, etc.

loans.name: Rosana

texts.en:
Rosana is 38 years old and married with six children, five of whom in school, Rosana works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a buy and sell charcoal in the Philippines and requested a PHP 16000 loan through NWTF to buy additional sacks of charcoal to sell.

Rosana has been in this business for 16 years.

In the future Rosana would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Horomsim

texts.en:
Horomsim is 58 years old and she with her beloved husband in Tsovagyugh village of Gegharkunik region. Horomsim has no higher education and many years she worked as a carpet weaver. Now she and her husband are busy with their farming works and their farm cattle care. Farming is the only source of income for their family and they work hard and all day long in order to have income from it. The cattle in the farm are a lot; they have cows, calves, a bull, a pig, sheep and chickens. So only the sale of their farm products makes their living.

Horomsim last times is very worried of her husband health conditions since nearly all the works about their farm he used to do alone not allowing Horomsim to get tired, but now he has some health hardships and he cannot work for a long time feeling weak and unhealthy. This loan of 700.000 Armenian drams she asks as her husband must pass medical examination in order to find the problem that causes great discomfort to her beloved husband.

loans.use: loan amount she asks as her husband must pass medical examination in order to find the problem that causes great discomfort to her beloved husband

loans.name: Kangaroo Group

texts.en:
Nyadzisai is the Chairperson of the Kangaroo group, which consists of four hardworking and committed women. They attended all the training sessions as required by Thrive and got their first loan this month, which they believe will improve their businesses. Nyadzisai is a widow aged 56, her husband died 10 years ago and she has been struggling to provide for her children alone through harsh economic conditions.  Nyadzisai has been a vendor since the death of her husband and she sells beverages, confectionaries, airtime and other small items.
 In the early stages of her business, she was operating a gate side stall but in 2010, she managed to move to a roadside stall along a busy road, which is commonly used by buses that ferry people to and from the capital city. She also managed to attend a cake baking class and now she bakes cakes for birthday parties, weddings and other events.  She says that her business has enabled her to pay school fees of her children. As a group, they are applying for a combined loan of $1150 payable in six months and Nyadzisai wants to use her portion to increase the stock at her stall as demand is high were she is situated.

loans.use: to increase stock and expand her product range in her roadside stall.

loans.name: Charbel

texts.en: Charbel is a 20 year old Lebanese single man living with his parents and two siblings, still attending school. Her father and mother are the main income source in the family in order to fulfill the family needs. Charbel in parallel with his study, he works as a hairdresser in a barber shop for extra money. Today, he is applying for a loan from kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. to pay his university educational fees. He states that this loan will help him to pursue a good educational level.

loans.use: to pay his university educational fees

loans.name: Virgen Asunta Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “VIRGEN ASUNTA”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de Anta, perteneciente a la provincia de Anta y departamento de Cusco. 

La socia es la Sra. Dora ella es soltera y tiene 33 años; La socia trabaja en su negocio de restaurant, la socia es una mujer emprendedora que por medio de este negocio la socia quiere que sus hijos que terminen de estudiar, el sueño de la socia es tener un restaurant grande. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar pollo, verduras, arroz y carne.

Los otros socios se dedican al negocio de venta de leche, negocio de venta de verduras, negocio de tienda de abarrotes y negocio de venta de comida. 

La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The members belong to the communal bank "Virgen Asunta". This bank is located in the district of Anta, belonging to the Anta province and department of Cusco.

The member is Señora Dora. She is single and 33 years old. She works in her restaurant. Dora is a hard-working woman who through the means of this business wants to see her children finish school. Her dream is to have a large restaurant. She asks for the loan in order to buy chicken, vegetables, rice, and meat.

The other members make a living in businesses like milk sales, vegetable sales, a grocery store, and the sale of food.

Dora is grateful to all those who are part of her dream in this manner, and promises to complete her repayments in the established term.

loans.use: to buy chicken, vegetables, rice, and meat.

loans.name: Valeriano

texts.en: Valeriano is 78 years old, a widower and a pensioner member in Paglaum MPC Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. He is a father of one adult age child. Recently, he avails a loan  to pay for a medical check up and purchase of maintenance medicines.

loans.use: to pay for medical check up and purchase of maintenance medicines

loans.name: San Jose De Media Luna Group

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “SAN JOSE DE MEDIA LUNA”.
La socia Vilma tiene 33 años de edad tiene 01 hijo y es soltera, la socia alterna sus actividades diarias dedicándose al negocio de venta de cereales, la socia es una persona responsable y empeñosa, la socia lleva años dedicándose a trabajar el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, siendo de esta manera que la socia saca adelante a su familia, la socia se siente agradecida por el crédito y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de cereales entre otros.
Los socios en general se sienten  agradecidos  por el crédito otorgado y se comprometen a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
El socio que sale en la foto adjunta pidio permiso para llegar tarde a la reunion por motivos de trabajo.
texts.en:
The borrower belongs to the "San Jose de Media Luna" communal bank. Vilma is 33 years old. She has one son and is single. She alternates her daily activities, working in the sale of cereals. She is a responsible, hardworking person. She has worked for years, which has gone well, thanks to the effort she puts into her business each day. In this manner she moves her family forward.

She is thankful for the loan, and promises to comply with the required payments. She seeks the loan for the purchase of cereals, among other things. The borrowers in general are thankful for the loan provided, and promise to comply with the required payments.

The borrower who appears in the individual photo arrived late to the meeting with permission, because of work reasons.

loans.use: to buy cereals among other things.

loans.name: Magdaline

texts.en: Magdaline is a married woman. She has 1 child. She operates a retail business where she sells sugar, bread, flour,cereals and other items. She has been involved in this business for 3 years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be price fluctuations. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of bread, soap, rice, cereals, sugar and other items. Her business goal is to open other branches within 5 years. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to open another branch.

loans.use: to buy more stock of bread, soap, rice, cereals, sugar and other items.

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en: Jackson is a married man. He has 6 children. He describes himself to be ambitious. He operates a motorcycle repair business. He has been involved in this business for 10 years. His business is located in a good area and his primary customers are regular. He describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. He will use the Kes 30,000 loan to buy more motorcycle repair parts. His business goal is to have more business outlets within 5 years. This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully. He will use the anticipated profits to set up a car wash.

loans.use: to buy more motorcycle repair parts

loans.name: Generosa

texts.en:
Generosa is 67 years old and married. She works very hard to provide for her family.

Generosa runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 5,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items to sell, such as canned goods, snack foods, home care products and other groceries.

Generosa has been in this business for 25 years and sells a variety of items, such as soft drinks, soap, snack foods, candies, biscuits, shampoo, fabric conditioner and other groceries.

In the future, Generosa would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell, such as canned goods, snack foods, home care products and other groceries.

loans.name: Dolphina

texts.en:
“When poor smallholder women farmers come together, they are powerful,” says Dolphina, a 38-year-old farmer who has 6 children and lives in the village of Gitwamba in the Kitale area of Kenya. As a small girl she watched women in her village form groups so as to access loan facilities. The memory of this collective effort led her to join Kibora tall tree self-help group. For the past year, Dolphina has been actively involved in mixed farming. Because she is from a remote village women do the heavy work in the field. This has not been a setback because Dolphina has been making great profits in farming. Kitale is one of the places with conditions that favor horticulture farming: good climate, soils, transport system, and market.

Dolphina has always wanted to diversify and start horticultural farming, but the biggest challenge she has been facing is lack of funds. She is therefore requesting a loan to start horticultural farming. Through the Kibora tall tree self-help group, whose members co-guarantee each other to secure a loan, Dolphina joined Juhudi Kilimo, a micro-finance organization that supports young and enterprising farmers. With your loan Dolphina intends to buy good quality vegetable seeds, flowers and potatoes. Proximity to an airstrip will allow her to transport the produce faster to an international market, hence enabling her to make more money. This loan will improve Dolphina's living conditions and secure the future of her children. The difficult circumstances that Dolphina has been through and her drive to overcome them, make her deserving of the help she requests.

loans.use: to start horticulture farming.

loans.name: Mwiti

texts.en:
Mwiti (left) is a 28-year-old smallholder farmer based in central Kenya. In the profile picture, he is seen standing next to his proud father.

Mwiti is married and has a child. He makes a living doing livestock farming, and milk is his main source of income.

The major challenge that Mwiti is facing is poor access to transportation services. Mwiti is seeking a loan to buy a reasonably-priced motorcycle made in India for rural markets in developing countries. This motorcycle is affordable, cheap to maintain and can handle the rough terrain found in rural areas. With the motorcycle, Mwiti will be able to distribute his produce in new locations far from his home.

Your loan investment will enable Mwiti to participate in formal markets where he will get better prices for his product, grow interdependent relationships and explore new opportunities.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Dauglas

texts.en:
Dauglas and his family live in a rural home in North Rift, Kenya. He, his wife and three children enjoy dairy farming, for it is their livelihood and source of income. He sells his farm product at a local market near his farm. Most of the income he generates goes to household and business-related expenses.

Dauglas is seeking a loan to complete the construction of the cowshed for his cows. The borrowed money will be used to buy construction tools and materials to get the project done.

He projects the animals’ health and welfare will be improved as a result of the loan investment. This will further lead to improved milk production and income.

Your loan investment will help Dauglas and his family elevate their livelihoods and lead a more comfortable life.

loans.use: to construct a cowshed.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Five years ago, Caroline started farming on a small inherited piece of land in Simat, a remote village in the Eldoret area of Kenya. Today, this humble mother of two children sells milk, eggs and a variety of food crops. She is a passionate farmer and, because of the immense knowledge she has about farming, commands a lot of respect from other farmers in her village.

Dairy farming is close to her heart, and she is proud to wake up every day to milk her cow. Although she makes profits by selling milk, she lacks a proper dairy unit and is seeking a loan to build one. A good dairy unit provides a place where cows can relax, and also prevents them from coming down with diseases that may arise because of being exposed to harsh weather such as rain.

Caroline believes that, through this loan, her living conditions will change because she will have an increase in milk production. She will save the money that she used to spend on treating her cows because she lacked a good dairy unit.

Caroline thanks Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: to build a modern dairy.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline is a woman eager to get ahead. She is a 47-year-old mother who lives with her family in the Kitale area of Kenya. She is blessed with a lovely family, which is her greatest motivation in life to persevere because she wants to provide a better future for them.

Pauline was unable to study to work in a professional career because of the economic situation that her family faced. However, she never gave up and has been practicing farming for the past ten years. She is an early riser who goes to her farm to earn a living; she has space there to use for dairy farming.

Pauline has requested a loan to buy a dairy cow. Kitale is an area that has a high population and there is a high demand for milk. Pauline, being an enterprising person, wants to take full advantage of that need and earn extra income. She hopes that this loan will allow her to change her standard of living and expand her milk-selling business. Once she has accumulated more profits, she plans to open a very large milk-selling business in the nearby shopping center and package milk.

Pauline wants to be economically empowered. She knows that accessing funds is challenging, but with partners such as Juhudi Kilimo and KIVA, she feels relieved to know that all her dreams will be achieved. With this loan, she will be able to provide a secure future for her children and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy another dairy cow

loans.name: Western Group

texts.en:
Every day she walks around the neighbourhood with a beaming smile carrying small bottles of cleaning agents selling them. At church meetings or women’s fellowship seminars she advertises her products hoping to get new customers and retain her old ones. She also sells to small companies and saloons around her area. This is her life, her bread and butter. She has no choice but to be good in what she does for her survival and that of her son depends on her business. Stella knows that the marketing mix begins with the product itself hence the effort she puts in producing thick and high quality dish washing-up liquid, shampoo and toilet cleaning liquids. She does not cut corners or reduce the ingredients so as to produce plenty but inferior products, Stella mixes all the right quantities that produce quality.

Western group is the name of the group that Stella Chairs. She is the group representative the one who leads during meetings and the one who has to see that all is in order. The group has four members who stay within close proximity to each other. The women have a shared history and have been involved in neighbourhood Roscas together. They have built trust over the years based on borrowing and lending from each other. The group joined Thrive Microfinance in August 2015 and attended training sessions and applied for loans to enable them to grow their businesses.

Stella is widowed with one school going child who is her biggest motivator to work hard. She is 35 years old and residing at her parent’s house. Stella is planning on procuring more ingredients to produce more of her cleaning agents. She also plans to properly package and brand her products so that her products are competitive. In future she is planning on adding the production of more cleaning agents to her business for variety and start a small cleaning company.

loans.use: to buy more ingredients to produce more of her cleaning agents and improve their packaging.

loans.name: Asia

texts.en:
Asia is 36 years old and lives in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. She has to work hard to feed her family. She is living with her two children and spouse.

To manage her household expenses, she owns a small home tailoring business. Asia has been stitching clothes for many years. Her youngest daughter has been helping and learning tailoring work and now has gotten a lot of experience. Asia wants to buy a new Juki machine so that she can contribute to her income by sewing cloth.

Asia requested a loan from Kiva’s field partner BRAC Pakistan, so she can buy a new Juki sewing machine for herself.

Asia wants to save money so she can arrange her daughter's marriage ceremony.

She give thanks to Kiva and field partner, BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy a new Juki sewing machine for her tailoring work.

loans.name: Justo

texts.es:
Justo es un hombre de 40 años de edad, casado, tiene 2 hijos de 4 y 6 años y una hija de 11 años, y su negocio es la carpintería.
El es buen padre, emprendedor y muy responsable. Su negocio lo realiza en la zona ’16 de julio’ caracterizada por el comercio informal en todas las áreas.
Justo es moreno de baja estatura y físico delgado, su lengua materna es el Aymara y habla español, su vida la comparte con su esposa que trabaja y con sus hijos que estudian en la escuela, viven en una casa propiedad de la familia que cuenta con todos los servicios básicos. Su negocio es la carpintería, el se especializa en la fabricación de todo tipo de puertas, “vendo puertas en mi taller y viajo a otras ciudades a vender por encargo…” comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es que cuenta con clientes en varias ciudades, la desventaja es la falta de dinero para comprar madera por mayor. Su sueño es estabilizar su negocio y vender mayor cantidad a otras ciudades, él desea comprar madera por mayor para fabricar puertas. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 20 años que se dedica a este negocio.
Es por esos motivos que Justo solicita un préstamo para comprar madera por mayor para fabricar puertas.
texts.en:
Justo is a 40 year-old married man with two sons who are 4 and 6 years old, and an 11 year-old daughter. His has a carpentry business. He is a good father and is enterprising and very responsible. He runs his business in the "16th of July" neighborhood, which is known for the informal commerce that is everywhere.

Justo has dark hair, and is of short stature and a thin physique. His native language is Aymara and he also speaks Spanish. He shares his life with his wife who also works, and his children who go to school. They live in a home on their family's property with all the basic services.

He works as a carpenter and specializes in making doors of all kinds. "I sell doors in my workshop and I travel to other cities to sell special orders", he says. The advantage of his business is that he has clients in various cities. The disadvantage is the lack of money to purchase wood wholesale.

His dream is to establish his business and make more sales in other cities. Justo wants to buy wood wholesale so that he can produce doors. This is why he is applying for the loan, which is the first loan he has applied for with the institution in the 20 years he has been in this business.

loans.use: to purchase wood wholesale in order to make doors.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is a hard-working entrepreneur with four children.

She has a general store in the Philippines and requested a 12,000 PHP loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell. She industriously earns additional income through other business ventures, such as a food-vending business.

Erlinda dreams that one day she will be able to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Hayk

texts.en:
This young farmer lives in Gavar city of Gegharkunik region with his nice wife and two children. Hayk has a higher education; he graduated from Gavar State University in computer programming. Despite having a profession in great demand, in his city he has not managed to find work in his specialty. If he left his city and moved to Yerevan, Hayk would surely find a job, but he cannot imagine his life anywhere but his native city and here he started farming.

Now in his farm he has cows — heifers and calves. He sells a great amount of milk, macun (national dairy product), cheese, butter and beef. Hayk loves his farm, and he works all day long and dreams of becoming richer with cattle. He would like to start swine breeding in the future, but for now he would like to buy one more cow and also fodder for all his farm cattle. For these purchases, he needs this Kiva loan in an amount 700,000 Armenian drams.

loans.use: to buy one more cow and also fodder for all his cattle.

loans.name: Tecla

texts.en:
Thirty-one-year-old Tecla has never set foot in any higher learning institution, but she is an accomplished farmer from the Nandihills area of Kenya, and commands a lot of respect. She is happily married and, together with her handsome husband, is blessed with four adorable children.

For the past ten years, she has been involved in mixed farming, and because of the immense knowledge she has of farming, farmers from her village seek technical advice from her on the best dairy farming techniques.

Tecla is the breadwinner of her family, and this really pushes her to work hard, so that her children will have a bright future and her parents will have a comfortable life. Although she makes a profit from farming, she is not comfortable and has always wanted to increase her income by selling cereals.

That is why she is seeking this loan to buy cereals.

Kenya's Nandihills area, one of the country's populated regions, has a high demand for cereals. This means that Tecla could increase her profits and satisfy the demand that is there. Accessing funds has been a challenge for Tecla, but she now feels relieved because Juhudi Kilimo is partnering with Kiva lenders to help aspiring women farmers like her turn their farming dreams into reality through training and loan financing.

Tecla believes that this loan will be of much help, and that she will be able to satisfy the demand for cereals. She also believes that the extra income she earns will enable a permanent change in her life and increase her business. Increased profits will allow Tecla to repay this loan and secure the future of her school-going children.

Be inspired make a loan to keep her big smile!

loans.use: To buy cereals

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul and his family live in a rural home in South Rift, Kenya. He enjoys dairy farming both as a livelihood and source of income.

Paul started farming many years ago, and now his plan is to only get bigger and better at it. He sells raw milk at a local market near his farm. Most of the income he generates goes to household and business-related expenses.

Paul is seeking a loan to construct a cowshed for his cows. The borrowed money will be used to buy construction tools and materials to get the project done.

He projects the animals’ health and welfare will be improved as a result of the loan investment. This will further lead to improved milk production and income.

Your loan investment will help Paul and his family elevate their livelihoods and lead a more comfortable life.

loans.use: to buy the construction materials for a cowshed

loans.name: Phibian

texts.en:
A simple woman, hardworking and full of life: this is Phibian. She is a 22-year-old woman with a great future ahead of her.

For the past four years, Phibian has been actively involved in mixed farming. As she is from rural Kenya, gender roles still adhere. Women do the heavy work of fetching and carrying water and wood, in addition to household chores, childcare, and tending crops. Many are left to run farms alone while their husbands migrate in search of paid employment. This has not been a setback because Phibian has been making great profits in dairy farming.

Kitale is one of the places with conditions that favor horticulture farming: good climate, soil, a transport system, and a market. Phibian has always wanted to diversify and start horticultural farming, but the biggest challenge she faces is the lack of funds. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to start horticultural farming.

Through the Top Juu self-help group, whose members co-guarantee each other to secure a loan, Phibian joined Juhudi Kilimo, a microfinance organization that supports young and enterprising farmers. With this loan, she intends to buy good quality vegetable seeds, flowers, and potatoes. Proximity to an airstrip will allow her to transport the produce faster to an international market, enabling her to make more money.
